Medicines that come in blister pack packaging are often taken for granted by people who are not on maintenance medication. However, people who frequently have to pop on a pill from a bottle or blister pack will have days where they have to ask a question: why bother with blister pack when a bottle seems better?

Anti-tampering

Did you know that those child-resistant bottle caps can easily be opened by preschoolers? The study published in the Journal of Pediatrics in August 2013 seems to confirm this fact. Although the tamper-proof bottles have saved countless of young kids’ lives since the 1970s, there are still 60,000 visits to the emergency room each year over accidental ingestion of medicine.

How can blister pack packaging be tamper-proof when it can be argued that it’s easier to open than child-resistant cap? You would have known that somebody popped a pill (and how many) because the canister would break open.

Track those pills

Second advantage of blister pack packaging is to easily track the number of pills you have already taken. It can be quite a pain to transfer each pill from the bottle to the pill sorter so you can track your intake. If you forget one pill, it’s easier to compensate. This is even crucial for birth control pills where missing one could have dire consequences.

Better quality

Some medicines are also quite sensitive to air, moisture and even light as they would impact on the chemical components of the drug. You might have noticed that some medicines come in opaque canister. This is especially ordered during the thermoforming of plastic in order to block sunlight because the pill is photo-reactive.

Besides, pills that come in blister pack packaging are easier to carry around that a bottle because the pills rattle around every time you move.
